item.title: How to use pgbench to test PostgreSQL® performance
item.description: Testing a database performance is a must in every company. Despite everyone’s needs beings slightly different, a good starting point for PostgreSQL® database is using pgbench: a tool shipped with the PostgreSQL installation that allows you to stress test a local or remote database. This blog post showcases how to install (on a Mac) and use pgbench to create load on a remote PostgreSQL database on Aiven.

item.title: 11 Lessons to learn when using NULLs in PostgreSQL®
item.description:
A boolean value should only contain two values, True or False, but is it correct? Usually people assume so, but sometimes miss the fact that there could be the absence of the value all-together. In databases this is absence is usually stored as NULL and this blog showcases how to find them, use them properly and 11 lessons to learn to be a NULL Pro!

Keep in mind, it’s not only booleans that can contain NULL values, it’s all the columns where you don’t define a NOT NULL constraint!

item.title: How to load JSON data in PostgreSQL with the COPY command
item.description:
You have a JSON dataset that you want to upload to a PostgreSQL table containing properly formatted rows and columns… How do you do it?

All the main sources like my own blog and others tell you to load the JSON in a dedicated temporary table containing a unique JSON column, then parse it and load into the target table. However there could be another way, avoiding the temp table!

item.title: What are the differences between JSON or JSONB in PostgreSQL®?
item.description:
PostgreSQL® offers two types of data types to handle JSON data:

  • JSON stores the JSON as text, performing a validation on the correctness of the JSON syntax
  • JSONB optimizes the JSON storage in a custom binary format. Therefore, on top of validating the correctness of the JSON format, time is spent to properly parse and store the content.
